title: Khajuraho Group of Monuments
summary: The Khajuraho Group of Monuments, located in Chhatarpur district, Madhya Pradesh, India, is a collection of Hindu and Jain temples. Famous for their Nagara-style architectural symbolism and some erotic sculptures, most were constructed by the Chandela dynasty between 885 CE and 1000 CE. Originally numbering 85 temples, only about 25 survive today. The complex, including the intricately detailed Kandariya Mahadeva Temple, was overgrown by jungle until its rediscovery by Captain T.S. Burt in 1838. These monuments exemplify a tradition of religious acceptance and served an educational purpose. They were inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1986 due to their outstanding architecture and testimony to the Chandela civilization.

current_status: Approximately 25 temples remain out of an original 85. They are actively preserved as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1986, attracting tourists and scholars for their unique architecture, sculptures, and historical significance.
future_prospects: Continued preservation and maintenance efforts as a UNESCO World Heritage Site are expected. Further archaeological research and historical studies may uncover more insights into the Chandela period and the site's significance. The monuments are likely to remain a major cultural and historical tourism destination in India.
